content.title: What is Cryptocurrency?
content.content: Cryptocurrency is digital money that exists only online. Think of it like digital coins that you can send to anyone in the world, just like sending an email. Unlike regular money that banks control, cryptocurrency is decentralized - no single person or company controls it.
learning_objectives: Know how it differs from traditional money
Recognize the benefits of digital currency
examples: Bitcoin is like digital gold
Ethereum is like a digital computer
You can send crypto to anyone, anywhere, anytime
analogies: Like email vs regular mail - faster and cheaper
Like digital photos vs printed photos - can be copied perfectly
Like online banking but without the bank

content.title: What is a Blockchain?
content.content: A blockchain is like a digital notebook that everyone can see and verify. Once something is written in it, it can't be erased or changed. It's like a public record that thousands of computers around the world keep copies of, making it nearly impossible to hack or cheat.
learning_objectives: Know why it's secure and trustworthy
examples: Like a public ledger that everyone can see
Like a chain of blocks, each connected to the previous one
Like a digital fingerprint that can't be faked
analogies: Like a public library where everyone can read the books
Like a digital voting booth that records every vote
Like a digital notary that verifies documents

content.title: What is a Wallet?
content.content: A crypto wallet is like a digital version of your physical wallet, but for cryptocurrency. It stores your digital money and lets you send and receive it. There are two main types: hot wallets (connected to internet) and cold wallets (offline for extra security).
learning_objectives: Understand what a crypto wallet is
Know the difference between hot and cold wallets
Learn how to keep your wallet secure
examples: MetaMask is a popular hot wallet
Hardware wallets like Ledger are cold wallets
Your wallet has a public address (like an email) and a private key (like a password)
analogies: Like a digital bank account but you control it
Like a digital safe with a special key
Like a digital ID card for your crypto

content.title: What is Trading?
content.content: Trading is buying and selling things to make a profit. In crypto, you buy tokens when you think the price will go up, and sell when you think it will go down. It's like buying low and selling high, but with digital assets instead of physical goods.
learning_objectives: Know the basic concept of buying low and selling high
examples: Buy Bitcoin at $30,000, sell at $40,000 = $10,000 profit
Buy Ethereum at $2,000, sell at $1,500 = $500 loss
Day trading means buying and selling within the same day
analogies: Like buying and selling stocks, but with crypto
Like buying a house and selling it for more later
Like trading cards - buy low, sell high

content.title: Long vs Short Positions
content.content: A 'long' position means you buy something hoping the price goes up. A 'short' position means you bet the price will go down (more advanced). Most beginners start with long positions - buying and holding crypto they believe in.
learning_objectives: Know when to use each strategy
examples: Long: Buy Bitcoin at $30,000, hope it goes to $50,000
Short: Borrow Bitcoin, sell it at $30,000, buy back at $20,000
Most people start with long positions
analogies: Long is like buying a house hoping it appreciates
Short is like betting against a sports team
Long is like planting a seed and waiting for it to grow

content.title: What is DeFi?
content.content: DeFi (Decentralized Finance) is like traditional banking, but without banks. You can lend, borrow, and trade directly with other people through smart contracts. It's like having a bank that runs automatically on code, with no human managers.
learning_objectives: Know how it differs from traditional finance
examples: Lend your crypto and earn interest automatically
Borrow money using your crypto as collateral
Trade tokens without a centralized exchange
analogies: Like a bank but run by code instead of people
Like a vending machine for financial services
Like a digital marketplace for money

content.title: What is a DEX?
content.content: A DEX (Decentralized Exchange) is like a stock market for cryptocurrency, but it runs automatically without a central authority controlling it. You can trade tokens directly with other people through smart contracts, without needing to trust a middleman.
learning_objectives: Know how it differs from centralized exchanges
Recognize the benefits of decentralized trading
examples: Uniswap is a popular DEX on Ethereum
Aerodrome is a DEX on Base
You provide liquidity and earn fees
analogies: Like a farmers market but for crypto
Like a vending machine that trades tokens
Like a digital auction house

content.title: How to Stay Safe in Crypto
content.content: Never share your private keys or seed phrases with anyone. Always double-check website URLs. Start with small amounts to learn safely. Use hardware wallets for large amounts. Be suspicious of anything that sounds too good to be true.
learning_objectives: Know how to protect private keys
examples: Never share your 12-word seed phrase
Always verify you're on the correct website
Start with $10-20 to learn safely
analogies: Like keeping your house keys safe
Like checking the address before entering a building
Like learning to swim in shallow water first

content.title: What is Base?
content.content: Base is a Layer 2 blockchain built by Coinbase. It's faster and cheaper than Ethereum, making it perfect for everyday crypto activities. Think of it as a faster highway built on top of Ethereum's security.
learning_objectives: Know why it's faster and cheaper
examples: Base transactions cost less than $0.01
Base is built by Coinbase but is decentralized
You can bridge ETH from Ethereum to Base
analogies: Like a fast lane on a highway
Like a local branch of a big bank
Like a shortcut that's still connected to the main road

content.title: Dollar Cost Averaging (DCA)
content.content: Dollar Cost Averaging means buying a fixed amount of crypto regularly, regardless of price. It's like putting money into a savings account every month. This strategy reduces the impact of price volatility and helps you build wealth over time.
learning_objectives: Know how it reduces volatility impact
examples: Buy $100 of Bitcoin every month
Buy $50 of Ethereum every week
Set up automatic purchases
analogies: Like contributing to a 401k every month
Like buying groceries regularly regardless of price
Like saving money in a piggy bank

content.title: Risk Management
content.content: Never invest more than you can afford to lose. Diversify your portfolio across different assets. Set stop-losses to limit losses. Don't put all your eggs in one basket. Start small and learn as you go.
learning_objectives: Know how to diversify a portfolio
examples: Only invest 5% of your savings in crypto
Don't put all money in one token
Set a stop-loss at 20% down
analogies: Like wearing a seatbelt when driving
Like having different types of insurance
Like not putting all your money in one stock
